title: Asymptotic Estimation, Interpolation and Extrapolation
text: Asymptotic estimation always best choice, example comparing diversity poorly-sampled communities: lower sample coverage can chosen limit uncertainty estimation. estimation level may sample size sample coverage converted internally sample size. sample size smaller actual sample, entropy interpolated. higher, entropy must extrapolated. diversity orders equal 0 (richness), 1 (Shannon) 2 (Simpson), explicit, almost unbiased estimators used. Continuity estimation diversity around actual sample size guaranteed.  non-integer orders, things get complicated. divent, asymptotic entropy estimated unveiled jackknife estimator rarefied actual sample size. reason correspond exactly observed entropy. asymptotic richness less robust part estimation thus adjusted iteratively rarefied entropy equals actual sample’s entropy, ensuring continuity interpolation extrapolation. default arguments functions apply strategy, except Simpson’s diversity (\(q=2\)) estimated directly without bias.
code: # Actual sample coverage coverage(paracou_6_abd[1, ]) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   site      weight estimator  coverage ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 ZhangHuang    0.911 # Diversity at half the sample size (interpolated) paracou6_1_size <- abd_sum(paracou_6_abd[1, ], as_numeric = TRUE) div_hill(paracou_6_abd[1, ], q = 1, level = round(paracou6_1_size / 2)) ## # A tibble: 1 × 6 ##   site      weight estimator     order level diversity ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 Interpolation     1   471      67.6 # Sample size corresponding to 90% coverage coverage_to_size(paracou_6_abd[1, ], sample_coverage = 0.9) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   site      weight sample_coverage  size ##   <chr>      <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56             0.9   819 # Diversity at 90% sample coverage div_hill(paracou_6_abd[1, ], q = 1, level = 0.9) ## # A tibble: 1 × 6 ##   site      weight estimator     order level diversity ##   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 subplot_1   1.56 Interpolation     1   819      75.4 # Simpson diversity at levels from 0.9 to 1.1 times the sample size accum_hill(   paracou_6_abd[1, ],   q = 2,   levels = round(0.9 * paracou6_1_size):round(1.1 * paracou6_1_size)) %>%    autoplot()

title: Asymptotic Estimation, Interpolation and Extrapolation
text: iNEXT (Hsieh, Ma, Chao 2016) designed primarily interpolate extrapolate diversity integer orders. Extrapolation diversity order 0 relies Chao1 estimator richness order 1 uses Chao-Jost estimator. divent, extrapolation relies estimation asymptotic distribution community asymptotic richness entropy asymptotic distribution rarefied observed sample size equals observed entropy data. approach allows consistent estimation extrapolated diversity integer non-integer orders, thus allowing consistent diversity profiles without discontinuities \(q=0\) \(q=1\). results iNEXT can obtained forcing argument estimator = "ChaoJost". Small differences due different estimators sample coverage: divent uses accurate ZhangHuang estimator default. Last, confidence intervals diversity accumulation assume normality iNEXT: estimation variance estimated bootstrap confidence interval defined \(\pm 1.96\) times standard deviation. divent, confidence intervals built directly quantiles bootstrapped estimations.
code: library("iNEXT") data(spider) # Extrapolated diversity of an example dataset estimateD(spider$Girdled, level=300) ##   Assemblage   m        Method Order.q        SC        qD    qD.LCL    qD.UCL ## 1       data 300 Extrapolation       0 0.9579518 33.317733 25.804082 40.831384 ## 2       data 300 Extrapolation       1 0.9579518 12.869603 10.314593 15.424612 ## 3       data 300 Extrapolation       2 0.9579518  7.983882  5.993923  9.973841 # Similar estimation by divent div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 0, level = 300, estimator = "ChaoJost") ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 jackknife     0   300      33.5 div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 1, level = 300, estimator = "ChaoJost") ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2015      1   300      13.1 # Estimation at order 2 is explicit, with no optional choice div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 2, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2014      2   300      7.98 # Default estimation of divent div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 0, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 jackknife     0   300      33.5 div_hill(spider$Girdled, q = 1, level = 300) ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   estimator order level diversity ##   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1 Chao2015      1   300      13.1

code: library("stats") plot(   tree.hclust <- hclust(     as.dist(species_dist),      method = "average"   ),    hang = -0.01,    axes = F ) axis(2) tree.hclust$height ## [1] 1 2

title: Phylogenies in divent
text: Conversion phylo object straightforward.  Edge lengths divided 2 conversion, documented ?.phylo.hclust. suit needs. divent, edge lengths multiplied 2 conversion, phylo objects can identical phylogenies.
code: library("ape") plot(tree.phylo <- as.phylo(tree.hclust)) axis(1) tree.phylo$edge.length ## [1] 1.0 0.5 0.5 0.5 tree.phylo$edge.length <- 2 * tree.phylo$edge.length plot(tree.phylo) axis(1)

title: Phylogenies in divent
text: last conversion phylo phylog.  Edge lengths stored directly phylog objects. $droot component keeps distances tips root. $Wdist component dist (half distance matrix without zero-diagonal) whose values \(d_{s,t}=\sqrt{2 \delta_{s,t}^2}\), \(\delta_{s,t}\) distance species \(s\) ant \(t\). phylog trees supported divent converted hclust:
code: library("ade4") plot(tree.phylog <- hclust2phylog(tree.hclust)) axis(1) tree.phylog$droot ##    C    A    B Int1 Root  ##    2    2    2    1    0 tree.phylog$Wdist^2/2 ##   C A ## A 2   ## B 2 1 tree2.hclust <- stats::hclust(tree.phylog$Wdist^2 / 2, "average") plot(tree2.hclust, hang = -0.01, axes = F) axis(2)

title: Spatial Diversity Accumulation of a Community — accum_sp_hill
text: X spatialized community (dbmss::wmppp object PointType values species names.) orders numeric vector: diversity orders address. Default 0. neighbors vector integers. Entropy accumulated along number neighbors around individual. Default 10% individuals. r vector distances. NULL accumulation along n, else neighbors accumulated circles radius r. correction edge-effect correction apply estimating entropy neighborhood community fit window. apply neighborhoods defined number neighbors. Default "none". "extrapolation" extrapolates observed diversity number individuals estimated full area neighborhood, slow. richness_estimator estimator richness evaluate total number species, see div_richness. used interpolation extrapolation. individual TRUE, individual neighborhood entropies returned. show_progress TRUE, progress bar shown long computations. check_arguments TRUE, function arguments verified. set FALSE save time arguments checked elsewhere. h0 null hypothesis compare distribution X . "none", default value, null hypothesis tested. "multinomial" means community rarefied number neighbors. "random location" means points randomly permuted across actual locations. "binomial" means points uniformly independently drawn window (binomial point process Poisson point process conditionally number points). alpha risk level, 5% default. n_simulations number simulations used estimate confidence envelope.

title: check_divent_args — check_divent_args
text: abd numeric vector containing abundances. abundances object class abundances. alpha risk level, 5% default. as_numeric TRUE, number numeric vector returned rather tibble. bootstrap method used obtain probabilities generate bootstrapped communities observed abundances. "Marcon2012", probabilities simply abundances divided total number individuals (Marcon et al. 2012) . "Chao2013" "Chao2015" (default), sophisticated approach used (see as_probabilities) following Chao et al. (2013)  Chao Jost (2015) . check_arguments TRUE, function arguments verified. set FALSE save time arguments checked elsewhere. correction edge-effect correction apply estimating number neighbors. coverage_estimator estimator sample coverage used coverage. distances distance matrix object class stats::dist. distribution distribution species abundances. May "lnorm" (log-normal), "lseries" (log-series), "geom" (geometric) "bstick" (broken stick). estimator estimator asymptotic entropy, diversity richness. fisher_alpha Fisher's \(\alpha\) log-series distribution. gamma TRUE, \(\gamma\) diversity, .e. diversity metacommunity, computed. global TRUE, global envelope sensu (Duranton Overman 2005)  calculated. jack_alpha risk level, 5% default, used optimize jackknife order. jack_max highest jackknife order allowed. Default 10. k order Hurlbert's diversity. level level interpolation extrapolation. may sample size (integer) sample coverage (number 0 1). NULL, asymptotic estimator ignored. n number observations. n_simulations number simulations used estimate confidence envelope. normalize TRUE, phylogenetic normalized: height tree set 1. orders orders diversity. prob numeric vector containing probabilities. prob_geom proportion resources taken successive species geometric distribution. probability_estimator string containing one possible estimators probability distribution (see probabilities). Used extrapolation. q number: order diversity. q_threshold value q diversity computed directly naive estimator \((sum{p_s^q}^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\), without computing entropy. q great, exponential entropy goes \(0^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\), causing rounding errors naive estimator diversity less less biased. r vector distances. rate decay rate exponential similarity. richness_estimator estimator richness evaluate total number species, see div_richness. used interpolation extrapolation. sample_coverage sample coverage x calculated elsewhere. Used calculate gamma diversity meta-communities, see details. sd_lnorm simulated log-normal distribution standard deviation. standard deviation log scale. show_progress TRUE, progress bar shown long computations. similarities similarity matrix, can obtained fun_similarity. default value identity matrix. size number individuals draw community. species_number number species. species_distribution object class species_distribution. thomas_mu Thomas point patterns, mean number points per cluster. intensity Poisson process cluster centers calculated number points (size) per area divided thomas_mu. thomas_scale Thomas point patterns, standard deviation random displacement (along coordinate axis) point cluster center. tree ultrametric, phylogenetic tree. May object class phylo_divent, ape::phylo, ade4::phylog stats::hclust. use.names TRUE, names species_distribution kept matrix vector converted . unveiling string containing one possible unveiling methods estimate probabilities unobserved species (see probabilities). Used extrapolation. weights weights sites species distributions. w_max maximum weight uniform distribution. w_mean mean weight exponential distribution (.e. negative inverse decay rate). w_min minimum weight uniform Weibull distribution. weibull_scale scale parameter Weibull distribution. weibull_shape shape parameter Weibull distribution. X spatialized community (dbmss::wmppp object PointType values species names.) win window containing point pattern. spatstat.geom::owin object. Default 1x1 square.

title: Number of Species of a Community — div_richness
text: Bias correction requires number individuals. Chao's estimation techniques Chao et al. (2014)  Chiu et al. (2014) . Jackknife estimator calculated straight adaptation code Ji-Ping Wang (jackknife package SPECIES). optimal order selected according Burnham Overton (1978); Burnham Overton (1979) . Many estimators available elsewhere, ones implemented necessary entropy estimations. Richness can estimated specified level interpolation extrapolation, either chosen sample size sample coverage (Chiu et al. 2014) , rather asymptotic value. Extrapolation relies estimation asymptotic richness. probability_estimator "naive", asymptotic estimation richness made using chosen estimator, else asymptotic distribution community derived estimated richness adjusted richness sample distribution size actual sample richness actual sample.

title: Deformed exponential — exp_q
text: deformed exponential reciprocal deformed logarithm (Tsallis 1994) , see ln_q. defined \((x(1-q)+1)^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\). \(q>1\), \(\ln_q{(+\infty)}=\frac{1}{(q-1)}\) \(\exp_q{(x)}\) defined \(x>\frac{1}{(q-1)}\). x close value, exponential severely subject rounding errors.

title: Deformed logarithm — ln_q
text: deformed logarithm (Tsallis 1994)  defined \(\ln_q{x}=\frac{(x^{(1-q)}-1)}{(1-q)}\). shape deformed logarithm similar regular one. \(\ln_1{x}=\log{x}\). \(q>1\), \(\ln_q{(+\infty)}=\frac{1}{(q-1)}\).

title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: x object. may : numeric vector containing abundances. may named track species names. object class species_distribution. ... Unused. estimator One estimators probability distribution: "naive" (default value), "Chao2013", "Chao2015", "ChaoShen" estimate probabilities observed species asymptotic distribution. unveiling One possible unveiling methods estimate probabilities unobserved species: "none" (default, species added), "uniform" (unobserved species probability) "geometric" (unobserved species distribution geometric). richness_estimator estimator richness evaluate total number species. "jackknife" default value. alternative "rarefy" estimate number species entropy asymptotic distribution rarefied observed sample size equals actual entropy data. jack_alpha risk level, 5% default, used optimize jackknife order. jack_max highest jackknife order allowed. Default 10. coverage_estimator estimator sample coverage used coverage. q order diversity. Default 0 richness. Used estimate asymptotic probability distributions argument richness_estimator "rarefy". , number unobserved species fitted entropy order q asymptotic probability distribution observed sample size equals actual entropy data. as_numeric TRUE, number numeric vector returned rather tibble. check_arguments TRUE, function arguments verified. set FALSE save time arguments checked elsewhere.

title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: object class "probabilities", species_distribution numeric vector argument as_numeric = TRUE.

title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: probabilities() estimates probability distribution sample. estimator "naive", observed abundance distribution used estimate actual probability distribution. list species changed: zero-abundance species cleared, unobserved species added. First, observed species probabilities estimated following Chao Shen (2003) , .e. input probabilities multiplied sample coverage, according sophisticated models: Chao et al. (2013) , single-parameter model, Chao Jost (2015) , two-parameter model. total probability observed species equals sample coverage. , distribution unobserved species can unveiled: number estimated according richness_estimator. coverage deficit (1 minus sample coverage) shared unobserved species equally (unveiling = "uniform", (Chao et al. 2013) ) according geometric distribution (unveiling = "geometric", (Chao Jost 2015) ).

title: Probabilities of Species — probabilities
text: Chao , Jost L (2015). “Estimating Diversity Entropy Profiles via Discovery Rates New Species.” Methods Ecology Evolution, 6(8), 873–882. doi:10.1111/2041-210X.12349 . Chao , Shen T (2003). “Nonparametric Estimation Shannon's Index Diversity Unseen Species Sample.” Environmental Ecological Statistics, 10(4), 429–443. doi:10.1023/:1026096204727 . Chao , Wang Y, Jost L (2013). “Entropy Species Accumulation Curve: Novel Entropy Estimator via Discovery Rates New Species.” Methods Ecology Evolution, 4(11), 1091–1100. doi:10.1111/2041-210x.12108 .

title: Diversity Profile of a Community — profile_hill
text: x object, may numeric vector containing abundances probabilities, object class abundances probabilities. orders orders diversity used build profile. ... Unused. estimator estimator entropy. level level interpolation extrapolation. may sample size (integer) sample coverage (number 0 1). NULL, asymptotic estimator ignored. probability_estimator string containing one possible estimators probability distribution (see probabilities). Used extrapolation. unveiling string containing one possible unveiling methods estimate probabilities unobserved species (see probabilities). Used extrapolation. richness_estimator estimator richness evaluate total number species, see div_richness. used interpolation extrapolation. jack_alpha risk level, 5% default, used optimize jackknife order. jack_max highest jackknife order allowed. Default 10. coverage_estimator estimator sample coverage used coverage. q_threshold value q diversity computed directly naive estimator \((sum{p_s^q}^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\), without computing entropy. q great, exponential entropy goes \(0^{\frac{1}{(1-q)}}\), causing rounding errors naive estimator diversity less less biased. sample_coverage sample coverage x calculated elsewhere. Used calculate gamma diversity meta-communities, see details. as_numeric TRUE, number numeric vector returned rather tibble. n_simulations number simulations used estimate confidence envelope profile. alpha risk level, 5% default, confidence envelope profile. bootstrap method used obtain probabilities generate bootstrapped communities observed abundances. "Marcon2012", probabilities simply abundances divided total number individuals (Marcon et al. 2012) . "Chao2013" "Chao2015" (default), sophisticated approach used (see as_probabilities) following Chao et al. title: Random communities — rcommunity
text: Communities fixed size drawn multinomial distribution according distribution probabilities provided prob. abundance vector abd may used instead probabilities, size default total number individuals vector. Random communities can built drawing multinomial law following Marcon et al. (2012) , trying estimate distribution actual community as_probabilities. bootstrap "Chao2013", distribution estimated single parameter model unobserved species given equal probabilities. bootstrap "Chao2015", two-parameter model used unobserved species follow geometric distribution. Alternatively, probabilities may drawn following classical distribution: either lognormal ("lnorm")  (Preston 1948)  given standard deviation (sd_lnorm; note mean actually normalizing constant. value set equal 0 simulation normal distribution unnormalized log-abundances), log-series ("lseries") (Fisher et al. 1943)  parameter fisher_alpha, geometric ("geom") (Motomura 1932)  parameter prob_geom, broken stick ("bstick") (MacArthur 1957) . number simulated species fixed species_number, except "lseries" obtained fisher_alpha size: \(S = \alpha \ln(1 + size / \alpha)\). Note probabilities drawn . number communities draw, n, greater 1, drawn multinomial distribution following probabilities. Log-normal, log-series broken-stick distributions stochastic. geometric distribution completely determined parameters. Spatialized communities include location individuals window, dbmss::wmppp object. Several point processes available, namely binomial (points uniformly distributed window) Thomas (1949) , clustered. Point weights, may instance size trees forest community, can uniform, follow Weibull negative exponential distribution. latter describe well diameter distribution trees forest (Rennolls et al. 1985; Turner 2004) .
